description.narrative: During 2018, based on the conclusions and recommendations of the mid-term review (MTR) of SSPDF that took place during February and March 2017, CNVP has improved the quality of the results’ monitoring framework, having produced a new Results Based Management (RBM) and Monitoring Plan (MP) (see Annex 1).In 2018, beneficiaries/users of JFM, the Municipalities and KFA have signed contracts to complete the process of JFM in two municipalities (Novo Berde and Kaçcanik). This is the second process of JFM that the state management of forests has delegated to a FFO, creating a partnership between KFA, the municipality and the FFO for sustainable forest management.The National Private Forest Owner Association (NAPFO) is the umbrella of 23 Associations of Private Forest Owner Associations (APFOs). It has continued to increase the capacities of its members on strategic planning, increasing membership, delivering services, promoting Women and Youth Producers Groups (WYPG) within APFOs, and increasing the level of participation of women in the steering bodies of APFOs.Linked to advocacy, the SSPDF project has continued to increase further the capacities of NAPFO and the APFOs. As a result, NAPFO has finalized an official document “Agenda 2018” (see Annex 5) where all important issues related to improvement of the legal framework conditions, policies and support to private forestry owners (PFO) have been ranked.NAPFO has continued to extend and strengthen its influence on decision-making bodies (policy decisions) realizing many meetings, drafting documents, and requesting improved management of the forestry sector in Kosovo.The SSPDF project during 2018 continued to organize events and round tables. It proposed amendments for a new draft law for forestry, as well as simplified procedures for logging wood for private forest owners. The advocacy process of NAPFO that relates to the new draft law on forestry has continued and resulted in including proposed amendments for JFM.The promotion of biomass production and its use for renewable energy in Kosovo has continued. The SSPDF project has promoted innovative approaches for increasing biomass production and using it to generate energy as a way of mitigating climate change.In this regard project, the project finalized five case study for municipalities that have potential for investment in decentralized district heating systems based on biomass. At the same time, this concept and case studies were discussed with main stakeholders in Kosovo, including the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Rural Development (MAFRD), the Ministry of Economic Development (MED), the Ministry of Local Government Administration (MLGA), the Ministry of Environment and Spatial Planning (MESP), municipalities, NAPFO and the APFOs.The project has been working to bring Sustainable Forest Management (SFM) in public forest ownership through the introduction of joint forest management (JFM) practices where local communities or associations take responsibility for the sustainable management of these forests.In private forests, the project has been supporting: the structure of private forest owners’ associations (NAFPO and APFO); further service delivery efforts to enhance sustainable management practices; the design and implementation of the legal and policy framework; and ways of adding value to forestry products through value chain development.The detailed actions taken by the SSPDF project in 2018 based on the annual work plan are described in Annex 2 (Activity database).As part of the capacity development measure related to private forestry management and JFM, the SSPDF project has increased the number of municipalities included under the JFM process (10 municipalities) as well as the number of management plans (MPs) prepared (74).The main accomplishment during 2018 is that stakeholders received the concept of JFM. This helps to ensure SFM which contributes to forestry protection, decreases the level of management informality, and brings more benefit for both the local community and the environment. This process enables the direct involvement of the community in managing public forest land, which did not exist before. Areas given for JFM are mainly degraded coppice forest which has been heavily impacted by uncontrolled logging, mainly for firewood. Forest protection can now be more easily managed through close coordination and cooperation with the local community.Local associations are continuously working with their members to increase membership, strengthen representation at regional and national level, involve women in forestry activities, and improve service delivery to members.During the year 4 field visits have been conducted by the Program manager and the Country manager. A visit form Sida HQ also took place in April 2018 to learn about the CNVP work in the field and meeting were organized with the representatives of the Associations of the Family Forest Owners in few municipalities and were CNVP presented work and the resulats of the woman producers groups within these assoatiations.
